bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Jessie Daniel Ames, November 5, 1929

div1.p: Kean informs Jessie Ames that physicians other than Roger Ames treated yellow fever patients at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Jessie Daniel Ames, November 5, 1929
div1.opener:
COPY
THE ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
THE MILITARY SURGEON
Washington, D. C.
November 5, 1929
Mrs. Jessie Daniel Ames,
409 Palmer Building,
Atlanta, Georgia.
My dear Mrs. Ames:
div1.p:
General Ireland with his remarkable memory may have the
names and details of thirty years ago at his finger tips, but I am
not blessed in that way. I can, of course, by looking up the records
give you the names of many of the doctors who had a hand in the
diagnoses and treatment of the yellow fever patients at Camp
Columbia and Camp Lazear in 1900. Major Reed in his reports mentions
the names of a number of the Havanna doctors that he had called in to
see his patients and verify the diagnosis. To find out, however,
just what the duties were of the medical officers who were at
Camp Columbia, and which ones had a hand in the treatment of yellow
fever patients is somewhat difficult. Also, just what good this
information will do you if I dig it up is not at all clear to me.

It was a great pleasure to make your acquaintance and
have that nice chat with you. After having met you I cannot
understand why my old friend, Dr. Ames, ever was willing to go
to Guatemala after his marriage.

closer.signed:
(Signed) J. R. Kean,
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd.
